title: Cham-Furth Depression
text:
The Cham-Furth Depression (, ) is a <a href="lowland">lowland</a> in the <a href="Upper%20Palatine-Bavarian%20Forest">Upper Palatine-Bavarian Forest</a> that separates the <a href="Upper%20Palatinate%20Forest">Upper Palatinate Forest</a> from the <a href="Bavarian%20Forest">Bavarian Forest</a>. At the same time it connects the <a href="Upper%20Palatinate">Upper Palatinate</a> with <a href="Bohemia">Bohemia</a>.
The German part has an area of 281 km², a length of 40 kilometres and a width of five to ten kilometres. The Czech part covers 206 km². The valley runs in a west-southwest-east northeast direction.
It is divided into the <a href="Cham%20%28Upper%20Palatinate%29">Cham</a> basin in the west at a height of 360 to 400 metres, which extends from <a href="Roding%2C%20Germany">Roding</a> roughly as far as <a href="Arnschwang">Arnschwang</a>, and the smaller <a href="Furth%20im%20Wald">Furth</a> depression in the east, which extends to Bohemia at heights of 400 to 500 metres. The Furth valley is bounded in the east by the <a href="European%20watershed">European watershed</a>. Its highest point is Kameňák ("Steinwald", 751 m) near Svatá Kateřina ("St. Katharina").
The geologically ancient depression is filled with <a href="Pleistocene">Pleistocene</a> and <a href="Holocene">alluvial</a> <a href="sedimentary%20rock">sediments</a> and drained by the rivers <a href="Chamb">Chamb</a> and <a href="Regen%20%28river%29">Regen</a> and their tributaries. These rivers <a href="meander">meander</a> through the undulating, hilly region.
In the Cham Basin, <a href="gneiss">gneiss</a>es and <a href="granite">granite</a>s predominate. In the Furth valley <a href="melanocratic">melanocratic</a> rock of the <a href="gabbro">gabbro</a>-<a href="amphibolite">amphibolite</a> mass is dominant. The climate is warmer and drier than the surrounding mountains, but winters are relatively cold and often characterized by "<a href="B%C3%B6hm%20%28wind%29">böhm</a>" winds from the east.
The hilltops of the typically rural landscape are covered with islands of spruce and pine. While the Cham Basin has been inhabited almost continuously since the <a href="Stone%20Age">Stone Age</a>, the Furth valley was not fully developed until the <a href="High%20Middle%20Ages">High Middle Ages</a>. <a href="Farming">Farming</a> dominates, followed by <a href="grassland">grassland</a> use.
The Cham-Furth Depression has always been an important communication route between Bavaria and Bohemia. Cham Castle, built around 976, guarded the eastern border of the Empire. The Bavarian-Bohemian border of the vast area has remained highly disputed throughout the early modern period, which led to different negotiations and agreements between the <a href="King%20of%20Bohemia">kings of Bohemia</a> and the <a href="Duke%20of%20Bavaria">dukes of Bavaria</a> in 1564, 1580, and finally in 1764. Today the area is part of the <a href="Upper%20Bavarian%20Forest%20Nature%20Park">Upper Bavarian Forest Nature Park</a>.
